topic.title: Is ZeroNet really censorship-proof?
topic.body:
Technically yes, anyone can create a zite, and let anyone leave comment on their zite.
But the zite owner indeed have the right to remove the content from a certain user.

Yes, the user, if not deleted local copies, can clone the zite and maintain the cloned in their own policy.
However, to be honest, how much traffic can a cloned zite gain?
If everyone want to speak completely freely, they better off maintaining their own zite.
Then how would their zite be discoverable (or searchable) to others?

If everyone post their zite address in well known zite like zeortalk or zerosites, will these well known zite be flooded with abused messages, and effectively make your zite un-discoverable?

topic.title: zeronet on zfs/btrfs with compression works well
topic.body:
zfs with compression (I'm using lz4) works well on javascript files and json files (which are majority on files on typical zites).

zfs is easy to setup, encourage others to try it out.

If you're running low in disk space, you can iteratively move files from your main partition to zfs partition.
In my case, my home directory is now hybrid ext4 & zfs on top of lvm.

**Caution**
A catch is if you've used >50% of disk space, it's impossible to migrate from zfs back to other partitions without additional harddisk because zfs cannot shrink or remove devices from the pool.

The only way to 'escape' is to copy files to other partitions when remove the whole zpool (you cannot iteratively release the space from zpool)

**Update**
The compressratio I got from zfs is 1.24x - 1.33x

If you want to have more aggressive compression (at the cost of more CPU cycle), you can use zstd.

**Update**
Just tested with btrfs, it also supports filesyetem compression without losing the flexibility to resize the partitions. Hence more preferable than zfs.

Btrfs doesn't have the lockdown problem when you've used >50% disk space.

1519293678_16LdT3GLYKemm8EWbR5BYXKMmMoZr.body:
IPFS features persistence, which means, avoid 404 (which is a problem on clearnet as well as zeronet).

Also, IPFS is immutable as @balancer73 pointed out. This means the content can not be deleted unless there's no peer for the file.

IPNS can act as the DNS, which point to the latest root folder of a website (IPFS hash). But IPNS is slower than zeronet because IPNS is cached for short time. If it's not cached, it will ask the original node (which can be slow).
On zeronet, the data are cached locally (forever) and updated in background.

For static site, both are suitable.
For real time webapp, IPFS alone is not enough. One can use WebRTC / other tech to fill the gap.
IPFS is developing pubsub feature, which seems to be on top of WebRTC (not sure) but the demo of pubsub is broken, seems recent update is a major change.

note that IPFS can also do dynamic webapp.
by using Ajax to ipns or the clearnet

1530111808_1EZTWytasXcKdiUFnN4KHqAfvg1nw.body:
In short, the current internet is centralized/decentralized, it is not peer-to-peer.
For example, the IP address is hierarchical. Let me use an non-technical example to illustrate this situation.

Two students Alice and Bob, in different university want to send mail to each other, really, the paper mail.
First, Alice write the message in a letter, then put it in a envelope.
Before actually, sending the mail to the hand of Bob, Alice hand the mail to a mailing officer in University A.
Then, the mail is passed to district A.
Then, a mail sender from the Government take the mail from University A.
Then, the mail is dispatched to district B.
Then, the mail is dispatched to University B.
Then, the mail is put into the mailbox of Bob in the mailing house of University B, maybe an on-campus apartment.

Anyone between Alice and Bob can decide to drop the mail, when he doesn't want to serve Alice or Bob.

An wrong concept you may be having is, two computer on the internet barely connect to each other directly.
Instead, they relay on other computers between them to pass (proxy) the messages.

This limitation cannot be solved no matter using Domain Name, IP, or even NDN (named data network) because they devices are not connected to each other directly.

1599297078_1HMvhRJegHrC92gxZhrPBeATg69tZ.body:
From technical point of view, IPFS probably has larger adoption because it's easier to be integrated into other systems. I've done that several times.

Zeronet is more often used along, rather than being part of other systems.

From the operation point of view, it's easier to clean up unneeded content from zeronet than from ipfs. Also, content discovery is better supported by zeronet.

Combining zeronet and ipfs seems to be a good idea. We may adopt ipfs (or it's file system design) for content deduplication.
For the networking (and seeding part), ipfs works generically. Each node may relay content that is not interested on that node, hence the networking seems more robust while zeronet node can only download content from peers that has seeded the specific zite content. Hence it is harder to share unpopular content on zeronet.
(please correct me if I get it wrong)

Inherent by the different in networking and seeding strategy, it is much easier to share IPFS link to "outsider" (those who has not installed any additional software).

For zeronet link, it's tricky to share to "outsider". There are some clearnet proxy but they are not often available and they mostly employ whitelisting on relative low number of zite)

1621945542_1DLBhCccN3MbM5YmzNS2UfBzDkEZk.body:
If we enable deduplication at file system level (zfs supports that), then we have less pressure to natively support deduplication by zeronet.

Having file system level deduplication helps to save disk space consumption but it doesn't helps to increase number of peer for the same resource on multiple zite (e.g. the same videos on multiple video zite)

If zeronet stores the files in ipfs style, the DX may be degraded, we can no longer edit the files in zite directory directly. Unless we make it "view mode" and "edit mode", and disable cross-zite deduplicate in the "edit mode". Sounds doable.

Just tested with btrfs, it also supports filesyetem compression without losing the flexibility to resize the partitions. Hence more preferable than zfs.

Btrfs doesn't have the lockdown problem when you've used >50% disk space.
